problem.p: Kepler’s Third Law is effective even in the case of a “degenerate” orbit, such as one that falls straight inward. In this case, the semi-major axis would be half of the distance to the center of the planet. Instead of finding a period for such an orbit, one could find the “time to crash” as half of the period. Therefore, an object crashing from a particular distance takes as much time as an object orbiting at one quarter of the distance. You will find that C > B > A = F > E > D.
